We would see that, if we double down on this and if we support companies in making investments in training and development in this space - all of the aspects that will encourage AI's growth - it will be an opportunity where we can be a leader rather than a follower. If we are a leader, that is where we will succeed and win investment and jobs, whereas if we are a follower, there is a risk that it could be damaging to growth.

I am interested in the positives and the negatives. I accept the negatives are infrastructure, housing and tariffs. Everyone does. It was the order they were in that caught me a bit on the hop when I was reading Mr. Sweetman's opening statement. On the positive side is the workforce and our tax levels, which are still attractive. That is number one. I want to get a feel for that and whether I am missing anything.

In relation to AI, I am interested in establishing whether, when it is discussing figures, the chamber is discussing the amount of turnover, the amount of employment or both. We are hearing all about AI, for example, that it is going to be very positive and we are going to try to lead the way, but will we lose jobs by gaining turnover?
I might hand the AI question to Mr. O'Callaghan.

On the Deputy's first question, the talent and skilled workforce is the number one reason companies are investing here. Anything that we can do to support the quality of life for that talent and skills base is essential: the scale of take-home pay right through to availability of crèche places and school places, the cost and availability of housing, etc. Anything that we can do to promote the desire of people with talent and skills to stay in or come to Ireland and to develop their lives here is going to be a real attractive piece for companies investing here because that is why they come here. They know that they can achieve far better through the Irish workforce than in many jurisdictions in the world.
Is it tax as well?

Tax is certainly important for individual workers. I mean anything that we can do to make it as attractive as possible. We must always look at what competing jurisdictions are offering, particularly for mobile workers who may make a decision to work somewhere in the globe and who look at their own Excel sheets and determine what things are going to make that attractive.
Will Mr. Sweetman give me the top three in terms of attractive? Is workforce the number one-----
Yes.
-----or is it tax?
Workforce is number one. Sixty-three percent of our members have said that workforce is number one. It is head and shoulders above the next.
Excellent.
Does that represent a change? Has that always been an outcome of the chamber's surveys?
Over the last number of years, it has consistently been talent and skills.

On the AI piece, we say 65% of our members are going to invest in AI or data analytics in the next 12 months and 60% in digital transformation or technology. That is investing in both the technology and the workforce. However, when we look at what members are going to do in terms of employee numbers, we see 93% of our members are either going to increase or maintain their workforce in the next 12 months.

The key challenge we are seeing in terms of workforce is the skills gaps where members are looking for workers. The top skills gaps are digital and data engineering and machine learning in AI, so there is a significant focus on attracting and developing skills in AI to really grasp the potential that is out there. That is a key focus in terms of getting and developing the talent and skills we need into the future. A key part of that is going to be upskilling and lifelong learning.
Is our education system helping the chamber in that or are we way behind?

There is a huge opportunity in terms of the engagement between universities and business. Businesses are reporting positive engagement with universities in that context and, indeed, in developing shorter term programmes. There is also a huge and important opportunity in the skills area in terms of apprenticeships and on-the-job learning, given the pace of technological change. I would say we are hearing very positive soundings from business on that but a lot of opportunity there.
I thank Mr. O'Callaghan.
The final speaker is Senator Stephenson.

In relation to AI, while I appreciate the issues of upskilling and moving people on, it would be interesting to hear whether the witnesses see any impact in terms of job losses. Obviously, that is something we hear about all the time. What have the witnesses considered in terms of the changing regulatory impact with the EU AI Act and will that have an impact on companies?

I noted in his opening statement that Mr. Sweetman stated that 92% of the chamber's membership wanted to maintain or grow employment. I wonder how that relates to so-called "high-quality jobs" in terms of permanent, unionised and well-paid jobs. That is obviously a big concern of ours. There is also the EU minimum wage directive, which has collective bargaining in it. It would be great to hear about whether the chamber's membership would support collective bargaining. The likes of Apple, Pfizer and Coca-Cola already have trade unions in place and I am wondering how the rest of the membership would react to that.

With regard to AI, the key to this is going to be getting ahead of it and making sure that we have upskilling opportunities and retraining capabilities for those who are going to be impacted by AI. At a global level, there will be people who will lose their jobs because of AI but there is also a net gain on employment because of the opportunities that AI provides. When we focus on Ireland, we are going to have to ask what pieces make sure that we are at the forefront of seeing this as an opportunity for growth. If we get ahead of it, if we provide the right research, development and innovation supports, if we provide the right training skills, and if we support the adoption of AI and how it can be used within organisations and within government, these are the things that are going to make us a market leader in various aspects. If we can achieve that, it will have a positive impact on employment in Ireland.

In terms of the EU AI Act, this is something that we need to be cognisant of. It is a broader issue of the regulatory burden and the regulatory regime that are facing companies within Europe. Through the US company lens, what they want to see is a level playing field. Every piece of legislation that we can focus on to achieve that is something that we need to make sure Ireland speaks up on. While the EU AI Act is relatively new, more broadly speaking, the competitiveness challenges that the US is saying it has with Europe have long been stated over the past two or three decades. It is not unique to the time we are in. It is just coming more to the fore now.

In terms of the growth in employment, this is 92% of chamber members who are going to maintain or increase. Sixty percent is the number who are going to increase, and 32% are going to maintain employment. These are still incredibly positive figures.

In terms of growth, it is around high-quality employment. When you look at the investments that are being made here, they are strategic investments, be it in the delivery of advanced manufacturing drugs or in areas of cybersecurity, technology or delivering sophisticated products and managing sophisticated projects in service areas such as financial services. These are areas that are going to require high levels of skill. In many ways, that is the competitive advantage that we need to push to move up the value chain in terms of the capabilities we can offer and the roles that can come based on that. The more we can push that, the more sustainable and sticky those roles are going to be into the future.
Just to be clear, does AmCham's interpretation of quality jobs include the right to collective bargaining?
Our view of high-quality jobs is based on what those roles are within an organisation and how they provide strategic support to the global organisation and lead parts of that strategic organisation.
Does AmCham have a sense from its membership or from the surveys it does around collective bargaining and the right to unionisation?
When we talk about high-quality jobs, that does not come into the conversation.

Does AmCham survey its members on those questions? Does it include questions on collective bargaining and on member companies' interests in that area? Is that included in its surveying? I know it did a survey in July.
Yes, collective bargaining is something our organisations would not like to see introduced mandatorily.
They would not like to see it.
They would not like to see it introduced on a mandatory basis.

I would like to round off the discussion. We have been away and one of the things that came up was a feeling about the occupied territories Bill. Because it is a few months since we have gone into this in detail, bits and pieces keep coming back to me on the threads we have dealt with. Underpinning the boycott legislation is a fear of antisemitism. I think it is rooted in a fear of antisemitism.

I ask the witnesses to pass on to their members that it was stated here that no motive of this committee can be attributed to that. Very much on the record are the actions of the Israel Defense Forces and the Netanyahu government and the plight of innocent women and children, particularly, notwithstanding the horrific events of 7 October which the committee clearly acknowledges as well. We look forward to the opportunity to have a good discussion on that.

The witnesses' presence has been very informative and helpful. I thank the CEO, his director of advocacy and public affairs, Mr. O'Callaghan, and Ms O'Brien, who maintained a stoic silence throughout but was attentive to everything. I was very conscious of that. Perhaps they will look at inviting us to an informal after-Christmas event some time and will put that in their calendar. That would be useful. I would not like to see a year go by before we had a further discussion.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee went into private session at 4.52 p.m. and adjourned at 5.09 p.m. until 3 p.m. on Tuesday, 18 November 2025.
